### System info
- Playwright Version: [1.34.3]
- Operating System: [Ubuntu Server]
- Browser: [Chromium]
- Other info:


**Issue**

When I am running the play wright test through an ado pipeline all test cases inside the test suite are failing. This is happening only for the first time pipeline run trigger. When I'm re triggering the same pipeline run this issue is not showing up.

items.title: Play wright tests are failing when running test cases through ado pipeline. Error [TypeError: addToCache is not a function  at transformHook]

items.body:
Hello Team,
I am aware we have the concept of [soft assertion](https://playwright.dev/docs/test-assertions#soft-assertions) however the feature i am requesting is for non-assertion statements mainly the statements used to interact with an element in a debug mode

We have broken down our lengthy full E2E test in different modules with in the same spec. However because of shift left and early testing concepts we encounter changes in the attributes and properties of an element which is quite common for an application which is still being developed. 

The challenge however is we are unable to continue or complete the test until we fix / update all the change locators. Hence requesting to think about a feature that allow us to ignore steps when locator is incorrect and allows us to continue the E2E test atleast in debug mode. Sharing an example (which I know is not lengthy )

Assume this is in an E2E.spec.js and we have the following steps in it
Step 1 - Login into a web application
Step 2 - Create a  "New" record 
Step 3 - Change the record status to "In Progress"
Step 4 - Add images to the record
Step 5 - Change the record status to "For Review"
Step 6 - verify the image added and mark record as "Completed"
 
Supposedly if there is a development change for following locators which I would not be aware of until I run the complete test
- "New" record element in Step 2
- "In Progress" element in Step 3
-  "Add image" element in Step 4

And if I happen to run the test even using debug mode, I will not be able to step over to Step 3 without fixing the locator in Step 2. Once I fix locator in Step 2 and will run the test again , the test will fail in Step 3. And I have to repeat the process of fixing and re-running the test. This eats up lot of time and at times we spend more time than manual testing to be able to finish our E2E test

The idea is to have a feature in debug mode which allows me to skip over or ignore the step where playwright is unable to select an element due to incorrect locator . User will then step in and note the incorrect step, carry out the step manually and resume the test without needing to start all over again. Also playwright or in fact any users will not remember all the following steps that have been automated. So by skipping and proceeding they can easily refer to steps in playwright inspector and carry out with actions manually and fix them later in the day.
items.title: [Feature] - Similar to soft assertion, we need ability to ignore steps in debug mode when locator is incorrect to resume lengthy E2E tests.

items.body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do not delete this template ⚠️⚠️ -->

<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Playwright release to see if your issue has already been fixed -->
<!-- 💡 Provide enough information for us to be able to reproduce your issue locally -->

### System info
- Playwright Version: [v1.36.2]
- Operating System: [ macOS 11.5 ]
- Browser: [Chromium, Firefox, WebKit]

### Source code

- [x] I provided exact source code that allows reproducing the issue locally.

<!-- For simple cases, please provide a self-contained test file along with the config file -->
<!-- For larger cases, you can provide a GitHub repo you created for this issue -->
<!-- If we can not reproduce the problem locally, we won't be able to act on it -->
<!-- You can still file without the exact code and we will try to help, but if we can't repro, it will be closed -->

**Link to the GitHub repository with the repro**

[https://github.com/asdiver/mini-frontend-monitor](https://github.com/asdiver/mini-frontend-monitor)

**Steps**
- clone repository, use branch:main
- install & pnpm run test

**Expected**
The callback of PerformanceObserver be called to trigger report event
```js
console.log('this callback never be called');
const firstPaintObserver = new window.PerformanceObserver((list) => {
  console.log(list);
  const custom = new CustomEvent('report', { detail: list });
  window.dispatchEvent(custom);
});
```

**Actual**
The callback of PerformanceObserver never be called by calling evaluate and addScriptTag
UI Mode OUTPUT can prove that
items.title: [BUG] The callback of PerformanceObserver never be called by calling evaluate and addScriptTag

items.body:
Dear Playwright team,

I would like to request for tester ability to associate Playwright Test scripts with Azure DevOps Test Cases.
The most relevant documentations related to Azure DevOps test case association, you may refer [link ](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/devops/test/associate-automated-test-with-test-case?view=azure-devops) here.

Thank you,
Elton M.
items.title: [Feature] Support for associating specific test script to test case in Azure DevOps Test Plan

items.body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/discussions/24456
Originally posted by **ifduyue** July 27, 2023 Hello * ```python import re from playwright.sync_api import sync_playwright with sync_playwright() as playwright: browser = playwright.firefox.launch(headless=True) context = browser.new_context() page = context.new_page() page.set_content('''

one

two three four.

'''.strip()) for element in page.get_by_text(re.compile(r".", flags=re.IGNORECASE)).all(): print(f"got {element.text_content().strip()=}") ''' # output: got element.text_content().strip()='one' got element.text_content().strip()='three' got element.text_content().strip()='button one' got element.text_content().strip()='button two' # no two and four? ''' ``` I'm using playwright==1.36.0 and Firefox 115.0 (playwright build v1419)
```typescript import { chromium } from "playwright"; (async () => { const browser = await chromium.launch(); const context = await browser.newContext(); const page = await context.newPage(); page.setContent(`

one

two three four.

`); for (const elment of await page.getByText(/./i).all()) { const text = await elment.textContent(); console.log(`got ${text}`); } await context.close(); await browser.close(); })(); # output: got one got three got button one got button two ```
items.title: Why get_by_text missed some texts? (Python&Typescript MRE provided)

items.title: [BUG] Playwright fails to trigger the click, fill likes event in the selenium grid docker setup.

items.body:
### System info
- Playwright Version: [v1.36.2]
- Operating System: [macOS 13.5, ubuntu 20]
- Browser: [All]

**Config file**

```js
// playwright.config.ts
projects: [
    { 
      name: 'setup',
      testMatch: /.*\.setup\.ts/ 
    },

    {
      name: 'chromium',
      use: {
        ...devices['Desktop Chrome'],
        browserName: 'chromium',
        // storageState: 'storage/admin-api.json'
      },
      dependencies: ['setup']
    },
```

**Test file (self-contained)**

```js
// auth.setup.ts
import { test as setup } from '@playwright/test'

setup('auth setup', async ({ request } ) => {
    switch (ENV) {
      case 'dev':
          await authAs({request}, 'dev', 'admin', process.env.ADMIN_ROLE, process.env.ACCOUNT_PASSWORD)
          await authAs({request}, 'dev', 'user', process.env.USER_ROLE, process.env.ACCOUNT_PASSWORD)
          await authAs({request}, 'dev', 'it_support', process.env.IT_SUPPORT_ROLE, process.env.ACCOUNT_PASSWORD)
        break
      default:
        console.log("WARNING! ENV is not defined")
        break
    }
})

async function authAs({request}, env: String, role: String, account: String, password: String) {
  const response = await request.post(`https://api-${env}-***.com/auth/login`, { form: { 'username': `${account}`, 'password': `${password}` } })
  await request.storageState({path: `storage/${role}-api.json`})
  console.log(`=> auth status: [${response.status()}] on [${env}] for [ ${role} ] `) 
}
```

```js
// any test file 
test.use({ storageState: './storage/admin-api.json' })
```

**Steps**
- [Run the test]
- [I get 3 files: storage/admin-api.json , storage/user-api.json, storage/it_support-api.json]

**Expected**
All 3 files (storage/admin-api.json , storage/user-api.json, storage/it_support-api.json) contains different cookie's value

**Actual**
All 3 files contains the same data and data is equal of the latest run.
 In my case latest run is 
```await authAs({request}, 'dev', 'it_support', process.env.IT_SUPPORT_ROLE, process.env.ACCOUNT_PASSWORD)```
 In other words storage/admin-api.json will contain data of storage/it_support-api.json

I am not sure if it a bug of PW , cause I'm not good at typescript, but similar code worked well when I used auth using UI

P.S. The main idea of mine was to create several storage/${role}-api.json before all kind of tests and use particular role further in test I need.
items.title: [BUG] The same data in multiple *-storage.json

items.body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do not delete this template ⚠️⚠️ -->

<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Playwright release to see if your issue has already been fixed -->
<!-- 💡 Provide enough information for us to be able to reproduce your issue locally -->

Ideally this test would be screen-agnostic so that regardless of the screen setup, the test would pass.

### System info
- Playwright Version: v1.35.1
- Operating System: macOS 13.4.1(c)
- Browser: Chromium

### Source code

**Config file**

```js
// playwright.config.ts
import { defineConfig, devices } from '@playwright/test';

export default defineConfig({
  projects: [
    {
      name: 'chromium',
      use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'], },
    },
});
```

**Test file (self-contained)**

```js
import { expect, test } from "@playwright/test";

// Headed mode
test.use({ headless: false });

it('should render PDF in iframe', async ({ page }) => {
    // Renders the smallest pdf: https://github.com/mathiasbynens/small/blob/master/pdf.pdf
    await page.setContent(`<iframe id="pdf" src="data:application/pdf;base64,JVBERi0xLgoxIDAgb2JqPDwvUGFnZXMgMiAwIFI+PmVuZG9iagoyIDAgb2JqPDwvS2lkc1szIDAgUl0vQ291bnQgMT4+ZW5kb2JqCjMgMCBvYmo8PC9QYXJlbnQgMiAwIFI+PmVuZG9iagp0cmFpbGVyIDw8L1Jvb3QgMSAwIFI+Pg=="/>`);

    // Time to drag browser into another display
    await page.waitForTimeout(5000);

    expect(await page.locator("#pdf").screenshot({ scale: "css" })).toMatchSnapshot("pdf.png");
});
```

**Steps**
- Run the test with the headed browser taking a snapshot of the PDF on a HiDPI screen e.g. MacBook
- Repeat the above with a non-HiDPI screen

**Expected**

I am expecting the test to pass regardless of whether the snapshot was taken on a HiDPI screen or not, given that the device has remained unchanged and that scale is set to "css".

**Actual**
The test is failing, saying `The result for this "15207 pixels (ratio 0.33 of all image pixels) are different."`

**Documentation inconsistency**
Another thing I noticed was the inconsistency in documentation for the screenshot option `scale` under `types.d.ts` and the website, with the former saying it [defaults to `device`](https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/blob/77b1ec4a53425ae638d3b8ade1d0998d273db51f/packages/playwright-core/types/types.d.ts#L9877) and the latter saying it [defaults to `css`](https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/blob/77b1ec4a53425ae638d3b8ade1d0998d273db51f/packages/playwright-core/types/types.d.ts#L9877). It looks like it defaults to `device`, so the website documentation needs updating?
items.title: [BUG] Mismatch with snapshots taken in headed mode on HiDPI & non-HiDPI screens for an iframe pdf

- Other info: This issue happens recently, but only for edge not for chrome. We use playwright library.

### Source code
```ts
(async () => {
  const userDataDir = `${os.homedir()}${config.get('userDataDirectoryPath.windowsEdge')}`;
  const context = await chromium.launchPersistentContext(userDataDir, {
    channel: 'msedge',
    headless: false,
  });
  const page = context.pages()[0];
  await page.goto(config.get('loginUrl'));
})();
```

**Steps**
- Download repo and run tests with `npx playwright test`

**Expected**

I would expect "bente" in the console

**Actual**

The fixture halts at line 15, `console.log(execSync('node ./test-js-file.js').toString());` - and never continues...



**comments**

Please notice that the project has configured `type: "module"` in the root package.json. With this removed, it actually does work - so I think it has something to do with cjs/mjs, but I'm a bit unsure.

Running `node ./test-js-file.js` from the cmd line works without issues.

items.body:
+ `@playwright/test` has great set of assertions built in top of some of the built in asserts from `jest mactchers` which can be consumed from the library via `import {expect} from "@playwright/test"`. Examples are https://playwright.dev/docs/test-assertions#list-of-assertions

+ Would it be possible for exporting the `expect` matchers from Playwright test to be consumed by other test runners like `jest, @elastic/synthetics, etc..`. I am a maintainer on the later package and would be interested in swapping the jest expect matchers with the one from the PW test. 

+ Even if not a standalone package which might require structural change in the PW library itself, would it possible to add the `lib/matchers` to the export list on `playwright/test/package.json` ? https://github.com/microsoft/playwright/blob/d92fe16b76272afb19e7af5a2496f7efce45441d/packages/playwright-test/package.json#L11
```ts
exports: {
 "./lib/expect": "./lib/matchers/expect.js"
}
```

I am not sure if there are consequences in doing so, Since PW test relies on some of the functionalities associated with the PW-core. If this PW team thinks this approach is good enough, I am happy to do a PR.
items.title: [Feature] export @playwright/test expect matchers

items.body:
### System info
- "@playwright/test": "^1.34.3"
- Operating System: [Windows 10]
- Browser: [Chromium]
- Other info: 

I have several spec.js files with tests and I need to automatically run the server before running my tests. I used to have beforeAll hooks, where I spin up the server in each spec.js files (it worked fine) and now I need to avoid the usage of beforeAll hooks. I was trying to implement global setup instead. In my case I only need to spin up the server and no auth needed. Below you can find the structure and an error I receive when I run tests with global setup.


### Source code

Structure:
```
test-suites
        |
        |____playwright-tests
        |               |
        |               |____ui-tests
        |               |           |
        |               |           |____tests1.spec.js
        |               |           |____tests2.spec.js
        |               |           |____tests3.spec.js
        |               |____api-tests
        |                           |
        |                           |____tests1.spec.js
        |                           |____tests2.spec.js
        |                           |____tests3.spec.js
        |____global.setup.js
        |
        |____playwright.config.js
```


// playwright.config.js
```
module.exports = defineConfig({
  globalSetup: require.resolve('./global.setup'),
  projects: [
    {
      name: 'setup',
      testMatch: /global.setup\.js/,
    },
    {
      name: 'chromium',
      use: { ...devices['Desktop Chrome'] },
      dependencies: ['setup']
    },
})
```

//global.setup.js
```
import { test as setup } from '@playwright/test'
import { spawn } from 'child_process'

setup('start server', async ({}) => {
  const serverDirectory = 'C:/User/123/projects/123/test/test-server'
  process.chdir(serverDirectory)
  spawn('npm run start', {shell: true})
})
```
**Expected**
I expect my server to run, but seems like playwright doesn't see my global.setup.js file.

**Actual**
My tests fail with an error:
```
    Error: page.goto: net::ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED at http://localhost:8080/app 
    =========================== logs ===========================
    navigating to "http://localhost:8080/app", waiting until "load"
    ==========================================================
```
I would really appreciate any help!
items.title: [BUG] Global Setup with starting the server

items.body:
**Background**:
When taking headless browser screenshots, our team chooses to include scrollbars. This is because we have had bugs in the past where css like overflow settings can cause the scrollbar to not appear in production.

**Pain point**:
Unfortunately, this causes friction when developers have device scaling on their monitor, as the scrollbars appear larger when their windows scale settings are above 100%.

As mentioned in #17882, setting the [screenshot option scale](https://playwright.dev/docs/api/class-page#page-screenshot-option-scale) to css does not fix the issue - users with monitor scaling still see the larger scrollbars.

**Request**:
Make the css scaling option also affect the scroll bar size in headless mode.
items.title: [Feature] Change size of scrollbars when using screenshot option scale "css"
